items.title: Fiber Bundle Structure of $\Sigma_N$
items.content:
118: :label: rem-fiber-bundle-structure
119: 
120: The state space $\Sigma_N$ is naturally a fiber bundle:
121: 
122: **Base Space**: The constrained node configuration space modulo rotations:
123: 
124: $$
125: \mathcal{B}_N := \left\{\mathbf{x} \in (\mathbb{R}^4)^N : \sum_{i=1}^N x_i = 0\right\} / SO(4)
126: $$
127: 
128: where we quotient by the rotation group SO(4) because the Hamiltonian depends only on relative coordinates $x_i - x_j$ and their norms, which are rotationally invariant.
129: 
130: **Fiber**: Over each node configuration $\mathbf{x} \in \mathcal{B}_N$, the gauge field lives in:
131: 
132: $$
133: \mathcal{F}(\mathbf{x}) := (\text{SU}(N_c))^{E_N(\mathbf{x})}
134: $$
135: 
136: The dimension of this fiber is $|E_N(\mathbf{x})| \cdot \dim(\text{SU}(N_c)) = |E_N(\mathbf{x})| \cdot (N_c^2 - 1)$, which varies with the graph structure.
137: 
138: **Singularities**: The fiber dimension changes at configurations where the Delaunay triangulation topology changes. In $\mathbb{R}^4$, such topology changes occur when $d+2 = 6$ points become co-spherical (lie on a common 3-sphere), causing a 4-simplex to "flip" and reconnect differently. These singularities form a measure-zero algebraic variety in $\mathbb{R}^{4N}$.
139: 
140: **Well-Posedness**: Despite these singularities, the dynamics and invariant measure are well-defined:
141: 1. The Hamiltonian $H(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{U})$ is smooth everywhere (depends only on distances and gauge fields)
